div.head: A short and an absolute order of confession most requisite of all persons to be ouer loked before they confesse them.
div.p:
HAuing treated before of contricion, we will heare likewise shew a way how they shuld prepare & examine themselues, which often vse to be confessed: of whome many are combred, with gnawing scruples, for that they narrowly gropinge euery corner of their conscience, sometymes can finde nothing wherof to accuse themselues: whereby in the one side they knowinge
well, that they are not nor cānot be without the common spots of human imbecillitie: and not on the other side, findinge them, at the tyme when they should be clensed of them, are in great disquiet & anguish of mynd, fearing yt they are neuer rightly cōfessed.

Of this two causes may be alleaged, the one bicause it is very hard for a man to know himselfe in deade, and to serch throughly all the secret places of his conscience, according to this sayinge of ye dropher, Psal. 18. who knoweth his excesses? O Lord deliuer me from my hydden offences.

The other cause is for that thē faults of the iust, who (as Salomon sayth, Prou. 24. Fall seuen tymes a daye) are rather the faults of omitting good thinges, then of committing euil. But for the playner explication hereof, it is euident, that all offences are commissiue or omissiue, that is either by committinge robbery, murder, or other dishonesty, or els by omittinge and neglectinge his dutie, in louing GOD, in fasting, in praying. &c.

Now of these two sortes of sinz whereas the first consisteth in actiō, are very easy to be knowen:
but the other not consistinge in doing but in not doing, are more difficult, for that which is not cannot be decerned: and bicause the vertuous people syldome fall into these actuall offences: and the faultes of omission are harde to perceaue: Hense aryseth that they knowe not whereof to bee confessed, which so much afflicteth them.
But for the ease of suche persons I haue compose this briefe memoriall, wherein these kynde of sinnes, (I meane the faultes of omission) are chiefely treated of.

And for that these offences are either against god, or against our selues, or against our neighbour: For this cause I haue deuided them into thrée partes, wherein these three fortes of negligences shalbe spoken of: which sometymes be not veniall sinnes: yet they be alwayes imperfections: and may full oft be venial offences.
For those that desyre to be perfect, must accuse themselues of these thinges, yet not alwayes but sometymes, chiefely at the principall feastes.

div.head: Here foloweth the memoriall.
div.p: AFter that the penitent hath vttered the generall confession, before he enter into the perticuler rehersall of his offences, let hym accuse him selfe of these foure thinges folowing.
First for that he came to this sacrament, not prepared as he ought to bée: and for not vsinge sufficient diligence in the examinacion of his conscience.

Secondly, let him accuse himselfe bicause he hath not such sorow & repentaunce for his offēces:
and bicause he hath not that firme & ful intent to leaue them as is requisite.

Thirdly, for that he did not receue the dreadfull sacrament of the aulter with that puritie of conscience and deuotion as was conuenient: and for that after communion he was not so sober as he should haue béene.

Fourthly, let him blame himselfe, for not hauing trayuayled diligently in the amendment of his lyfe: and for not procedinge and profeting dayly in vertue & seruice of GOD: but rather to haue cōtinewed still in one kinde
of lasie slouthfulnesse, and perchaunce to haue reuoulted backwarde. After this, he may begin to accuse him selfe according to the direction that ensueth.

div.head: Towards God.
div.p: TOwardes God we ought to haue these thrée theologicall vertues which are Faith, Hope, and Charitie. In euery of these he maye accuse him selfe as foloweth.

Cōcerning charitie, for not hauīg
loued God, wyth all his harfe, and with hys soule, as was bounde to doe: But hath setled his affection in the disordered loue of creatures, and of the vanitie of this worlde, forgettinge his creator altogether.
Concerning fayth, for not beleueing so firmely as hée ought: And for not endeuoring speedely to repell, vayne thoughts and suggestions of the Dyuell tending to destroy or to weaken his fayth.

Concerning charytie, let hym blame hym selfe, if in any hys trobles gréefes or necessities, he
hath not reposed his sure hope & confidence in his sauiour and if hee hath labored ouer earnestly with his body and mynde to bée ridde of his miserie: For that it pr • céedth of lytle hope.

Concerning the puritie of intētion. For not performing the seruice of God, for the onely respect of his loue as in dutye hée was bounde: But for that hée hath done it somtymes for hys priuate auayle, somtymes for a custome, somtymes bycause they were conformable to his disiers &c.

He shoulde likewise accuse him
self to haue béene slowe in aunswering the diuine inspirations of God, often resisting the worke of the holy Ghost, this is a very spirituall and secret sore, worthy alway to sticke in our conscience.

In lyke naner for beinge ingratefull towards the benefites of god: and for not rendring vnto him due thanks therefore, and for that he hath not endeuoured to serue and loue more earnestly the giuer of al goodnesse.

Like wyse let him accuse himselfe, to haue forgotten his Lord, banishing him often times out of his harte: Whereas hée ought
to haue hym alwayes presente and fixed before his eyes.

Concerninge patience in aduersitie, let him bethinke hymselfe if he hath not (perchaunce) abidden pacient • ye, the scourge that god hath sēt him, & hath nor receiued it méekely at his hands as a medecin, nor hath not thāked hym therefore.
Further for that hee hath not exhibited dewe deuotion to the sacred places, nor at the tyme of masse to the holy function done there. Nor to the most blessed sacrament.

div.head: Towardes himselfe.
div.p: A Man hath in hym many parts, he hath a body with all hys members and sences, a soule with all his appetites, and a spirit wyth all hys poweres, that is vnderstanding, memory, and wil: and so may transgresse the rule and order he ought to obserue in euery of these

First then let hym accuse him selfe, for not dealing wyth his body, wyth such rigour and seuerytie as was conuenient, as well in meate, drinke, apparell
and sleape, as in al other things: Yea, for cheareshinge hys bodye two delycately, and for beinge ouer fauourable to himselfe.

For not restraining his imagination and other sences orderly: But rather wilfullye to suffer them to wander abrod, hearing, séeing, speaking, and imagining, sundrie idle and friuolus toyes, al which after resorting agayne vnto thy memory, doe cause him to be distracted in his prayers.

Let him also accuse himselfe, for not hauing mortified his appetites, nor wrastled with his will so violently as hee myght
haue done, yea, for the folowing and fulfilling thereof in euery degrée: And for that he is not so humble in hart and déed as is requisite: and for that hée doeth not accoumpt hymselfe so vyle and cwretched as hée is in dede, and therefore handleth not him selfe in such order as he best deserueth.
Lastly for that he is dull and neglygent in his prayers, sometymes intermitting them altogither, to folowe some vayne trifle or peuish businesse.

div.head: Towards his neighbour.
div.p: FIrst let him blame himselfe, for not bearing to his neighbour such affection as hee ought: for not releuing his néede with such fauour and belpe as he coulde and shoulde: For not hauing due compassion of his miserie, and for not praying to god for hym as was his parte.

And agayne, bycause he hath not felt so fully as hee ought, nor hath not had so hartye compassion as was due to the publycke and common calamytie of
the church, hapned bi war heresy &c. And that he hath not commended it to God as hee myght and shoulde haue done.

Those which haue superiours shoulde accuse themselues, for not shewing obedience and reuerence according to their dutye: And those that haue subiectes and children, shoulds accuse thēselues for not hauing instructed, chastened, or not prouyded for them thinges necessarie. And yt they haue not had such care of them as was conuenient.

div.head: Concerning actiue offences.
div.p:
When he hath in this sort accused
himself in ye faults of omissiō he may sodenly exhibit a like bill of complaynt agaynst hymselfe composed of the crymes called cōmissiue offences, by running ouer the ten commaundementes, the seuen capitall sinns. Blaming himself of all that his conscience shall accuse hym in euery of these. And if he require a more breife way, he may take a short and spéedy suruey. Ouer all his thoughtes, wordes and workes, nohing his defectes, in al these & accuse himself therof.

After all thys he must accuse himselfe of the crymes apperteining
to hys degrée, calling, and office, declaring that he hath don contrary to the rule and equitie of his vocation: As if he be a relygious man of his tryde vowe, if he be a iudge, phisicion, merchaunt, or lawyer, of thinges belonging to his office.

Hauing finished these accusations, let hym conclude his confession, saying of all these offences and of all others which I haue commytted in thought, worde, and dede, I blame, I accuse my selfe, and I saye vnto God, my faulte, my greuous guilt. And I request of thée O father which
heare presentest the parson of god, absolution and penaunce for them

div.head: Of the necessitye of confession: taken out of the catechisme which was alowed by the Counsell of Trident.
div.p:
NO man must thinke that our Lorde cōmaunded confession in such sorte, yt we may leaue the same vndone, if wee woulde. For euery christian ought to be thus perswaded, that whosoeuer hath committed mortall sin, ought to be called backe to spirituall lyfe, by the sacrament
of confession: The which thinge is playnely set out, in a goodly and metophoricall spéech of our Sauiour, who calleth the authoritie of ministring this sacrament, the keay of the kingedome of heauen. For euen as no man can come in ani place, without hym who kéepeth the kayes: So is it meant, that none doe come to heauen, if the priestes (to whose custody our Lorde commytted his keyes) open not the doores. For if it were otherwise, it shoulde séeme the church shuld haue had the vse of the keyes to no purpose: And in vayne
shoulde he (who hath charge of the keyes) keepe men backe frō the entraunce to heauen, if so be there were any other passage, to enter in at. And Sainct Austen hath this notable saying, he saith let no man say in his mynde: I doe secreat penaunce vnto our Lorde God, who pardoneth my offences, he knoweth my hart: If this will serue, it was spoken without cause: Whose sins you forgiue in earth, shalbe forgiuē in heauen. And by thys meanes the keyes were giuen the church without cause. Sainct Ambrose also wryteth to the same effect,
in that booke where in hee refuseth the heresy of the Nouatians, who affirmed, ye our Lorde had reserued to his selfe onely to forgiue sinnes. Doth he rather honour God (sayeth he) who obayeth his ministers or he that withstandeth them. God commaunded vs, to bee obedient to his minysters: Whome when we obay, we doe honour to god onely. If a manne bee desirous to know when he is boūde to confession, let him vnderstand, that all sorte of christians ought to come there vnto, when they haue the perfect vse of reason:
That is euery one is bounde to be confessed, when he is able to discerne the good from the bad: And when noughtinesse maye take roote in hym. So when a manne is come to those yeares wherein he must consider howe to obtayne eternall lyfe: so sone he is bounde to confesse his sins to a priest, whereas no man, can loke for saluation, whose conscience is poluted with sinne. The church also in the same place and Canon before recited sheweth, what time men must resort to cōfessiō: which is, euery yeare once at the least each man muste bée
confessed. But if we way wyth our selues what is expedient for our soule health, then doubtles, when we are in daunger of life, or whē we are about some thing which must not be done of one yt is infected with sinne, (as when we either mynister or receyue, the holy sacramentes) so ofte we must of necessity vse confession. So we must doe also when wee stande in feare least wee shoulde forget any sinne: For neyther can we be cōfessed of those things which we haue forgetten: neyther doe we obtayne of god pardon for our sinnes: vnlesse they
be blotted out by penaunce.

div.head: The description of confession as it is a sacrament.
div.p:
THe sacrament of confession is such a kynde of accusation of our sinne, as is done to thys ende, that wee maye obtayne mercy, by the vertue of ye keyes. And for good cause is it called an accusation, bycause our sins are not so to be spoken of as though we bragged thereof, (as those vse to do, who reioyse when they haue done amisse) neyther are our sinnes to bee vttred in such
fort, as if we tolde a tale to delyte those that heare vs talke: But our sinnes must be spoken with such a mynde, that delyts in accusing of one his selfe, and that in such sort, that we are desirous to be reuenged of our selues therefore. Our sinnes are confessed, to the ende wee maye haue forgiuenes therof: for this maner of iudgement is vnlyke to common iudgementes which concerne lyfe and death: wherin such as confesse their faultes suffer payne and punishment, & are not quytt or pardoned their fault.

div.head: After what sort a godly confession must be made.
div.p: WE muste vse such care and diligēce in our confession as we vse in matters of greatest importaunce: And we ought to employ our labour in this, that we heale the woundes of our soule, and vtterly roote out all sinne.
True confession requireth these conditions folowing.

1 It must be done wholely and perfectly: Which thing is so necessary, that whosoeuer of purpose, omitteth any thing whych
ought to be spoken of and confessed, and vtter what els hee lusteth, he shall not onely receyue no commodity at all by that confession: But also much increaseth his former offences.
2 We must not be carelesse, or negligently examyne our conscience or to slyghtly call our faults to mynde, as that wee maye be worthely thought we would not remember them at all.

3 It must be simple, bare, and playne, and not sett out or colored by art: As some vse to doe, who rather giue reasons of their lyfe, then confesse theire faultes
done in their lyfe tyme.

4 Our confession ought to haue in it wisdome and shamefastnes. For we must not spend to many wordes herein, but breifely declare such thinges as pertayne to nature and condicion of euery sinne: And in such sort we must deale therein that modesty be also ioyned there vnto.

5 Secricy is also necessary. For both the priest that confesseth & the party confessed, ought to doo what he can, that the talke vsed in confession, be spoken secretly. For ye which cause it is not lawfull for any to make confessoin
of his sinnes, eyther by messenger or by letters: for so nothing shoulde be done secretly.

6 Confession must be done very often: For nothing shoulde bee such a care to a christian man as many tymes to come to confession, and thereby to clense and wash our soule. For when any hath offended God in deadly sin, nothing can be more commodyous to the auoydenge of many periles that hange ouer vs in thys lyfe, then presently to confesse our faultes. And whereas some vsing clenlynesse in apparell thincke also that clenlynesse
of dody maketh a man to lyue the longer: It is a foule matter we shoulde be so curious in these thinges and not to be as care full to wash away the spottes of the soule.
